label: H1

text: Shortly before 8:30 a.m. on Wednesday,
label: BODY

text: November 7, the cargo ship Cosco Busan—en
label: BODY

text: route to South Korea from the Port of Oakland—
label: BODY

text: ran into a support post for the Bay Bridge,
label: BODY

text: gashing its fuel tank and sending 58,000 gallons
label: BODY

text: of oil into San Francisco Bay. Initial reports by the
label: BODY

text: shipping company put the size of the spill at 400
label: BODY

text: gallons. Twelve hours later, local officials learned
label: BODY

text: the results of an initial investigation by state and
label: BODY

text: federal agencies—that the spill was over 100
label: BODY

text: times the size first reported.
label: BODY

text: When those first oily drops hit the water, no
label: BODY

text: booms were in place around the ship. So swirling
label: BODY

text: Bay currents spread the oil far and wide—hitting
label: BODY

text: shorelines from San Francisco to Berkeley to
label: BODY

text: Richmond to Marin—affecting birds, fish and
label: BODY

text: other wildlife throughout the Bay and as far out
label: BODY

text: as the Farallons.
label: BODY

text: The spill couldn’t have come at a worse time:
label: BODY

text: thousands of migratory birds spend their winter
label: BODY

text: months in the Estuary. Three weeks after the spill,
label: BODY

text: the official tally of oiled birds (dead and alive)
label: BODY

text: totaled close to 3,000, with potential bird mortal-
label: BODY

text: ity as high as 22,000 (see sidebar). More than
label: BODY

text: half of the birds accounted for died from expo-
label: BODY

text: sure to the oil.
label: BODY

text: Pictures of oiled ducks and other birds
label: BODY

text: appeared on page 1 of local papers, and these
label: BODY

text: images drove many people, like Nancy Powell of
label: BODY

text: Albany, to action. She decided on November 9—
label: BODY

text: a Friday—to walk north along the Bay from
label: BODY

text: Emeryville to see if there was oil to clean or birds
label: BODY

text: to save. She found six oiled birds in Berkeley,
label: BODY

text: across from Shorebird Park. No one was tending
label: BODY

text: to them, so she stood there to protect them.
label: BODY

text: While she stood by the birds, more concerned
label: BODY

text: people showed up, including a kayaker who ran
label: BODY

text: up from the water carrying an oiled bird. Nearby,
label: BODY

text: officials were busy discussing the proper way to
label: BODY

text: wear a Hazmat suit. Powell noticed that autho-
label: BODY

text: rized bird capture teams that were hastily being
label: BODY

text: assembled (consisting of state and federal
label: BODY

text: employees) were poorly equipped. “They had a
label: BODY

text: few trainees, no nets. No towels to put in boxes
label: BODY

text: to take the birds anywhere,” says Powell. “They
label: BODY

text: borrowed nets from the Shorebird Nature Center,
label: BODY

text: and they were able to catch a couple of birds on
label: BODY

text: that beach.”
label: BODY

text: Powell had seen a spill on the Bay ten years
label: BODY

text: ago, and she had helped cleaning oiled birds. So
label: BODY

text: she had experience, and serendipitously, she
label: BODY

text: found other would-be volunteers that morning at
label: BODY

text: Shorebird Park with backgrounds in wildlife res-
label: BODY

text: cue and a strong desire to do something. The
label: BODY

text: volunteers bought over $500 worth of fishing
label: BODY

text: nets and towels from local stores, and spent the
label: BODY

text: day helping rescue birds in Berkeley. The group
label: BODY

text: also recruited drivers to take birds to the Cordelia
label: BODY

text: wildlife center. Later, the unofficial group (warned
label: BODY

text: that they could be arrested) moved to Albany,
label: BODY

text: where they rescued birds and transported birds
label: BODY

text: being caught by homeless people.
label: BODY

text: When the group arrived at Hoffman Marsh on
label: BODY

text: the stretch of shoreline curving between Point
label: BODY

text: Isabelle and the Richmond Inner Harbor the third
label: BODY

text: day following the spill, they found oiled birds on
label: BODY

text: the rocks and beaches being chased by dogs and
label: BODY

text: their owners, but no one taking charge of the sit-
label: BODY

text: uation—not even to do crowd control.
label: BODY

text: “A Richmond fire truck was there, and he said,
label: BODY

text: ‘Yeah, I really think this trail should be closed off,
label: BODY

text: but I don’t have the authority to do it,’” said
label: BODY

text: Powell, who, along with other members of her
label: BODY

text: group, again took matters into their own hands.
label: BODY

text: They organized a bird-rescue network with peo-
label: BODY

text: ple handling tasks such as closing off the
label: BODY

text: shoreline, taking reports of oiled birds along the
label: BODY

text: shore, and catching and transporting birds. Over
label: BODY

text: the course of a week, says Powell, her group res-
label: BODY

text: cued over 50 birds.
label: BODY

text: “The person running the Oiled Wildlife Care
label: BODY

text: Network command center kept trying to tell me,
label: BODY

text: ‘You know, there is unauthorized collection of
label: BODY

text: birds going on,’” explains an incredulous Powell.
label: BODY

text: “And the message I kept sending back was that
label: BODY

text: ‘you get authorized people out here to cover this
label: BODY

text: waterfront, and we are gone immediately.’”
label: BODY

text: Powell and others working the Richmond
label: BODY

text: shoreline those first days after the spill say there
label: BODY

text: were a few authorized people on the waterfront
label: BODY

text: in Richmond—but only one or two people in a
label: BODY

text: truck with no cleanup—or bird capture—equip-
label: BODY

text: THE PRICE OF OIL
label: H4

text: The Cosco Busan
label: BODY

text: spill claimed the lives
label: BODY

text: of at least 45 species
label: BODY

text: of birds, ranging from
label: BODY

text: the pelagic northern
label: BODY

text: fulmar and parasitic
label: BODY

text: jaeger to the shore-
label: BODY

text: bound fox sparrow.
label: BODY

text: Some were hit harder
label: BODY

text: than others. First
label: BODY

text: impressions that most of
label: BODY

text: the oiled birds were surf scoters are sup-
label: BODY

text: ported by preliminary data from the
label: BODY

text: International Bird Rescue Research Center.
label: BODY

text: As of November 20, according to UC Davis
label: BODY

text: spokesperson Sylvia Wright, more than
label: BODY

text: twice as many surf scoters had been
label: BODY

text: brought in alive as the next most frequent
label: BODY

text: species, the western grebe. The scoters also
label: BODY

text: headed the list of species found dead, fol-
label: BODY

text: lowed again by western grebe.
label: BODY

text: The top ten species found alive also
label: BODY

text: included eared, horned, and Clark’s grebes,
label: BODY

text: greater and lesser scaup, and ruddy duck,
label: BODY

text: common loon, and common murre. All
label: BODY

text: these birds forage by diving from the sur-
label: BODY

text: face of the water (grebes, cormorants, and
label: BODY

text: murres are fish-eaters, while the three ducks
label: BODY

text: eat benthic mollusks and other aquatic
label: BODY

text: invertebrates.) Other foraging guilds—for
label: BODY

text: example, plunge-divers like terns and peli-
label: BODY

text: cans—appear to have been less affected.
label: BODY

text: The main exceptions: western gulls and
label: BODY

text: northern fulmars, significant numbers of
label: BODY

text: which were found dead.
label: BODY

text: The surf scoter is one of the most abun-
label: BODY

text: dant birds in San Francisco Bay in fall and
label: BODY

text: winter; over 75% of the North American
label: BODY

text: population congregates here. But local
label: BODY

text: Audubon Society Christmas Bird Counts
label: BODY

text: report higher totals for greater scaup than
label: BODY

text: for scoter, along with substantial numbers
label: BODY

text: for ruddy duck and bufflehead. Location
label: BODY

text: may account for some apparent patterns in
label: BODY

text: the spill. Southern Marin had the highest
label: BODY

text: CBC numbers for western grebe, which
label: BODY

text: ranked second to surf scoter among spill
label: BODY

text: victims; eared grebes, concentrated in the
label: BODY

text: South Bay, had fewer spill casualties.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: ment. In some cases, agency represen-
label: BODY

text: tatives were lost and needed
label: BODY

text: directions—and offered little in the way
label: BODY

text: of help. Late Saturday afternoon, a
label: BODY

text: truck of workers from the Contra Costa
label: BODY

text: Hazardous Materials Program came on
label: BODY

text: their own authority to clean the county
label: BODY

text: beaches and boom off the shoreline.
label: BODY

text: “They are real heroes in my book,”
label: BODY

text: says Powell. “Because the Coast Guard
label: BODY

text: apparently told all of the local agencies
label: BODY

text: to wait for direction from them and
label: BODY

text: Contra Costa said, ‘Nope.’”
label: BODY

text: But because this was the third day
label: BODY

text: after the spill, some of the work of the
label: BODY

text: county hazardous materials workers
label: BODY

text: had little effect—booms they were able
label: BODY

text: to put into the Bay actually hemmed in the oil
label: BODY

text: along the shoreline. Powell and others say these
label: BODY

text: workers were frustrated at not hearing sooner
label: BODY

text: about the extent of the spill. And they were ham-
label: BODY

text: strung by a lack of proper equipment. “They
label: BODY

text: actually wanted to boom off the Richmond
label: BODY

text: marsh, but they couldn’t get a boat,” says Powell.
label: BODY

text: The California Office of Oil Spill Prevention and
label: BODY

text: Response (“OSPR”)—under the aegis of Cal Fish
label: BODY

text: & Game—created a map of the Bay showing the
label: BODY

text: areas hardest hit by the spill. Richmond, which, at
label: BODY

text: 32 miles of shoreline, is the city with the longest
label: BODY

text: coastline on San Francisco Bay, is identified on the
label: BODY

text: map as among those areas. Hot spots included
label: BODY

text: Brooks Island, home to a bird sanctuary, and
label: BODY

text: Barbara and Jay Vincent Park, one of the locations
label: BODY

text: where Powell and her fellow volunteers worked.
label: BODY

text: With the exception of two bird capturers from
label: BODY

text: International Bird Rescue who showed up on
label: BODY

text: Monday and her grassroots group, says Powell,
label: BODY

text: no one from state or federal agencies rescued
label: BODY

text: birds in Richmond that first weekend.
label: BODY

text: The experiences of Powell and the others in
label: BODY

text: Richmond is a microcosm of the situation else-
label: BODY

text: where. The Environmental Water Caucus’ David
label: BODY

text: Nesmith reported a similar fiasco along the
label: BODY

text: Oakland shoreline. “It’s a scandal to have all of
label: BODY

text: this human infrastructure potential [volunteers]
label: BODY

text: out there and to not have used it. I think OSPR
label: BODY

text: completely screwed up on this.” Local officials
label: BODY

text: including Berkeley Assemblywoman Loni Hancock
label: BODY

text: also wanted to know why events unfolded the
label: BODY

text: way they did; Hancock convened the first hearing
label: BODY

text: looking into the spill in Emeryville on November
label: BODY

text: 15, nine days after the spill.
label: BODY

text: Present at this hearing was Greg Hurner,
label: BODY

text: deputy director of OSPR. He brought a four-inch
label: BODY

text: thick binder and recited chapter and verse from it
label: BODY

text: regarding the procedures followed by the agency,
label: BODY

text: the gallons of oil recovered, the numbers of skim-
label: BODY

text: mers on the Bay, and even the amount of boom
label: BODY

text: deployed. Still, none of that placated Hancock.
label: BODY

text: What she wanted was accountability.
label: BODY

text: “So my question to you, really, would be ... in
label: BODY

text: your best professional judgment, what went
label: BODY

text: wrong?” Hurner replied, “I’m not saying that any-
label: BODY

text: thing went wrong.”
label: BODY

text: Members of the packed audience gasped and
label: BODY

text: shook their heads in dismay at his response.
label: BODY

text: Hurner was not alone in this assessment. Four
label: BODY

text: days later, at a hearing in San Francisco’s Presidio,
label: BODY

text: a U.S. Congressional delegation that included
label: BODY

text: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-San Francisco) and
label: BODY

text: Congressman George Miller (D-Martinez), U.S.
label: BODY

text: Coast Guard Rear Admiral Craig Bone deemed the
label: BODY

text: cleanup effort, “one of the most successful
label: BODY

text: cleanups I’ve ever experienced.” Sylvia Wright,
label: BODY

text: with the Oiled Wildlife Care Network at UC Davis,
label: BODY

text: said that “While questions remain to be answered
label: BODY

text: about the spill response itself, there is no doubt
label: BODY

text: that the wildlife rescue effort was as successful as it
label: BODY

text: could possibly have been, thanks to long-range
label: BODY

text: planning and advance training of 1,000 wildlife
label: BODY

text: rescue individuals from throughout the state.”
label: BODY

text: Pelosi did not agree. “The people we represent are
label: BODY

text: not satisfied with this response,” she said.
label: BODY

text: Nor were some of the authorized wildlife
label: BODY

text: responders on the shoreline who spoke anony-
label: BODY

text: mously out of fear of losing their jobs. Said one,
label: BODY

text: “I really, really, really don’t want to be left in the
label: BODY

text: field again in California with only one dipnet for
label: BODY

text: equipment with 20 miles of shoreline to patrol
label: BODY

text: with hundreds of oiled birds everywhere I look.
label: BODY

text: Fish and Game has million of dollars to care for
label: BODY

text: these birds, and I get one lousy dipnet?”
label: BODY

text: As ESTUARY went to press, Hancock was hold-
label: BODY

text: ing another hearing and Pelosi pledged that
label: BODY

text: Congress would continue its probe; five Assembly
label: BODY

text: members have drafted new spill legislation while
label: BODY

text: five senators have demanded an independent
label: BODY

text: audit of Cal Fish & Game. Unified Command—a
label: BODY

text: joint agency made up of the Coast Guard, Cal
label: BODY

text: Fish & Game, and O’Brien Group, the firm hired
label: BODY

text: by the shipping company to deal with the spill—
label: BODY

text: began cleaning the Richmond Shoreline on
label: BODY

text: November 15, nine days after the accident.
label: BODY

text: Other variables may include how sus-
label: BODY

text: ceptible different species are to bunker oil.
label: BODY

text: Compared with crude oil, little is known
label: BODY

text: about the toxicity and persistence of
label: BODY

text: bunker oil, although it has been shown to
label: BODY

text: damage the reproductive systems of labo-
label: BODY

text: ratory mink. It varies chemically from batch
label: BODY

text: to batch; the exact content of the Cosco
label: BODY

text: Busan’s fuel is not yet known. One study
label: BODY

text: found that major oil spills in western
label: BODY

text: Europe doubled the winter mortality of
label: BODY

text: common murres, whether the culprit was
label: BODY

text: crude or bunker oil.
label: BODY

text: Endangered species affected by the spill
label: BODY

text: include marbled murrelet, western snowy
label: BODY

text: plover, and brown pelican. Several
label: BODY

text: Important Bird Areas, including Richardson
label: BODY

text: Bay, East Shore Wetlands, and Brooks Island
label: BODY

text: were impacted; Brooks Island’s breeding
label: BODY

text: Caspian terns were not home.
label: BODY

text: UC Davis researchers headed by Michael
label: BODY

text: Ziccardi and Greg Massey are using the
label: BODY

text: catastrophe to learn more about care and
label: BODY

text: survival of oiled birds. They plan to analyze
label: BODY

text: blood samples to determine the best pre-
label: BODY

text: dictors of survival and clarify the causes of
label: BODY

text: anemia in spill victims. Up to 30 birds will
label: BODY

text: be equipped with external radio transmit-
label: BODY

text: ters so their travels and survival can be
label: BODY

text: monitored once they’re released.
label: BODY

text: By November 30,
label: BODY

text: 338 rehabilitated
label: BODY

text: birds had been
label: BODY

text: returned to oil-free
label: BODY

text: shorelines in San
label: BODY

text: Mateo and Marin
label: BODY

text: Counties. The IBRRC
label: BODY

text: said 1,704 had
label: BODY

text: been found dead in
label: BODY

text: the field (977 visibly
label: BODY

text: oiled); another 586 had died or been euth-
label: BODY

text: anized at the rescue center. Many others
label: BODY

text: may have sunk in the Bay or the ocean, or
label: BODY

text: been eaten by predators and scavengers. If,
label: BODY

text: as is likely, only one of every ten casualties
label: BODY

text: is being retrieved, deaths resulting from
label: BODY

text: the spill could exceed 22,000.

text: Redefining Progress’s Gelobter drew parallels
label: BODY

text: between Hurricane Katrina and New Orleans
label: BODY

text: and the potential for similar disaster in the Delta
label: BODY

text: if we don’t take action to prevent it. If we were
label: BODY

text: to be pro-active in fixing the Delta, said
label: BODY

text: Gelobter, “we could be a model for the world.”
label: BODY

text: The panel session concluded with Gardner ask-
label: BODY

text: ing what the business community can do to
label: BODY

text: help protect the Bay and Delta. Wunderman
label: BODY

text: responded that we need to focus on better inte-
label: BODY

text: grating transit and development. “We made a
label: BODY

text: mistake,” said Wunderman. “We screwed it up
label: BODY

text: by not having the proper balance between
label: BODY

text: housing and public transit. But we’re beginning
label: BODY

text: to get it. It’s time to focus on the urban core
label: BODY

text: and develop a transit system that supports it.
label: BODY

text: We have to figure out how to overcome the
label: BODY

text: resistance to change that is inherent in the busi-
label: BODY

text: ness community.”
label: BODY

text: The late morning and afternoon sessions were
label: BODY

text: devoted to presentations on important changes
label: BODY

text: in the Estuary and how they will be managed.
label: BODY

text: The S.F. Regional Board’s Tom Mumley sug-
label: BODY

text: gested that with new pollutants constantly
label: BODY

text: emerging and possibly affecting water quality,
label: BODY

text: the state should consider adopting a “California
label: BODY

text: product stewardship council” that would require
label: BODY

text: manufacturers to adopt a “cradle-to-cradle”
label: BODY

text: approach for their products in order to reduce
label: BODY

text: waste and pollution. The Board’s Richard Looker
label: BODY

text: built on that theme, pointing out how many
label: BODY

text: societal benefits have a parallel environmental
label: BODY

text: impact: controlling pests can equal aquatic toxi-
label: BODY

text: city; preventing fires can lead to PBDEs in the
label: BODY

text: Bay and its wildlife; health and beauty products
label: BODY

text: not removed in wastewater treatment can dis-
label: BODY

text: rupt endocrine and other functions in fish; the
label: BODY

text: products and processes leading to economic
label: BODY

text: health have often led to long-lived environmen-
label: BODY

text: tal contaminants.

text: to cope. “The San Francisco water supply is

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the impacts climate change will have, particu-
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: “New Orleans East.” “We have created the same

text: The theme of this year’s State of the Estuary
label: BODY

text: conference was “A Greener Shade of Blue,” and
label: BODY

text: the conference returned a mixed verdict on
label: BODY

text: whether or not the Estuary and its watershed are
label: BODY

text: in fact “greener.” On an unusually rainy October
label: BODY

text: morning, Oakland city council president Jean
label: BODY

text: Fong welcomed a crowd of nearly 600 people to
label: BODY

text: the Scottish Rite Center on Lake Merritt’s shores,
label: BODY

text: reminding them that water quality and restora-
label: BODY

text: tion are a priority for Oakland, which was
label: BODY

text: recently named the country’s fifth-most-sustain-
label: BODY

text: able city and has passed Measure DD, which
label: BODY

text: provides $200 million to restore Lake Merritt and
label: BODY

text: Oakland’s creeks. Following Fong, ABAG’s Henry
label: BODY

text: Gardner, the Bay Area Council’s Jim Wunderman,
label: BODY

text: NRDC’s Barry Nelson, Delta Vision Blue Ribbon
label: BODY

text: Task Force’s Phil Isenberg, BCDC’s Will Travis, and
label: BODY

text: Redefining Progress’s Michel Gelobter brain-
label: BODY

text: stormed about the role of the Delta in the future
label: BODY

text: of the Bay Area.
label: BODY

text: “How can we balance social justice, sustain-
label: BODY

text: able development, and the environment while
label: BODY

text: moving forward with the Bay-Delta?” asked
label: BODY

text: Gardner. “Many cities granted conditional use
label: BODY

text: permits in the communities closest to the Bay in
label: BODY

text: low-income and minority communities to sup-
label: BODY

text: port a variety of business activities. That had a
label: BODY

text: devastating impact on some of those communi-
label: BODY

text: ties, conditions that persist today.”
label: BODY

text: Wunderman spoke of the Bay’s importance,
label: BODY

text: both as a draw for tourists, with 260,000 area
label: BODY

text: jobs devoted to tourism, and as a major attractor
label: BODY

text: of new residents. He also spoke of the Port of
label: BODY

text: Oakland’s importance as the fifth-largest port in
label: BODY

text: the United States and as a provider of blue-collar
label: BODY

text: jobs. “The Port of Oakland has tremendous
label: BODY

text: expansion capabilities consistent with the envi-
label: BODY

text: ronmental sustainability of the Bay,” Wunderman
label: BODY

text: declared. “It’s underutilized as a transportation
label: BODY

text: mechanism.” Wunderman assured the crowd
label: BODY

text: that the business community sees the health of
label: BODY

text: the Bay-Delta as critical.

text: BCDC’s Travis jumped right to climate
label: BODY

text: change. He predicted that all of the Bay previ-
label: BODY

text: ously lost to fill will eventually be reclaimed by
label: BODY

text: Bay waters. Other manifestations of climate
label: BODY

text: change will include more frequent storm surges,
label: BODY

text: heavy rains, high tides, and high winds, plus
label: BODY

text: extended droughts and wildfires, he warned.
label: BODY

text: “[Climate change] will have profound local
label: BODY

text: impacts. We need a plan that anticipates that.”
label: BODY

text: But the devil is in the details, he admitted. “How
label: BODY

text: do we plan a region and a Bay that will surely
label: BODY

text: get bigger? We are going to have to build a lot
label: BODY

text: of levees that are big enough and strong
label: BODY

text: enough to hold back floods around the airports.
label: BODY

text: We also need to take a hard look at where it
label: BODY

text: might be most cost-effective to remove existing
label: BODY

text: developments and replace them with wetlands,
label: BODY

text: which absorb floods and sequester carbon.” Also
label: BODY

text: on Travis’s to do list: “abandon any future plans
label: BODY

text: to develop low-lying areas.” Said Travis, “We
label: BODY

text: need a plan for the Estuary that is bold and
label: BODY

text: audacious. We’ve got to stop talking about how
label: BODY

text: to restore it to the way it was; we need to
label: BODY

text: design for different elevations, chemistry,
label: BODY

text: species, to do proactive management. The issue
label: BODY

text: is not whether we are playing God—we are
label: BODY

text: already doing that—but how to get it right.”
label: BODY

text: Isenberg addressed the Estuary’s political
label: BODY

text: geography. “Why are the Bay and Delta two dif-
label: BODY

text: ferent political regions despite being connected?
label: BODY

text: I say it is a pure artifact of notions of regional
label: BODY

text: self-importance—it’s human nature that each of
label: BODY

text: us is the center of the universe.” Isenberg told
label: BODY

text: the largely Bay Area crowd “your strength is
label: BODY

text: your weakness. You agreed on what it meant to
label: BODY

text: save the Bay, playing to the strength of regional
label: BODY

text: importance.” But now, the forgotten Delta must
label: BODY

text: take center stage, said Isenberg. The Delta Vision
label: BODY

text: Task Force was charged with creating a plan to
label: BODY

text: protect and improve the Delta ecosystem, said
label: BODY

text: Isenberg, while at the same time protecting and
label: BODY

text: improving the state’s water supply system. “The
label: BODY

text: Delta ecosystem is going to hell. Not one person
label: BODY

text: or organization has said that the Delta is in good
label: BODY

text: shape. [The Delta issue] is collectively much
label: BODY

text: more than the Bay Area because it’s the transfer
label: BODY

text: point of all the water that comes in. Where
label: BODY

text: should the state go on the question of the
label: BODY

text: ecosystem?” Isenberg pointed out that it is not
label: BODY

text: just the swimming pools of Southern California
label: BODY

text: and Coachella Valley taking water from the
label: BODY

text: Delta; it is also—and has been for a long time—
label: BODY

text: the Bay Area. “It can’t be ‘our water projects are
label: BODY

text: good, and theirs are bad.’”
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: face of the planet. It was an astonishing accom-

text: “The issue is not

text: whether we are
label: H3

text: playing God—we
label: H3

text: are already doing

text: that—but how to
label: H3

text: SFEI’s Josh Collins said scientists need
label: BODY

text: to come up with a new set of tools for
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: One positive change in Estuary man-
label: BODY

text: agement, according to BCDC’s Steve
label: BODY

text: Goldbeck, is the progress made in using
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: And Cal Fish & Game’s Susan Ellis
label: BODY

text: described another positive change, exemplified
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: quagga mussel invasion. “We had a unified
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: and federal agencies, Metropolitan Water
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The afternoon session focused on important
label: BODY

text: changes to aquatic resources and wildlife—fish,
label: BODY

text: mammals, and birds—in the Estuary. DWR’s Ted
label: BODY

text: Sommer reviewed the state of the latest science
label: BODY

text: on the “pelagic organism decline” (POD) of
label: BODY

text: Delta and longfin smelt, threadfin shad, and
label: BODY

text: striped bass. Probably the most pressing—and as
label: BODY

text: yet unanswered—question is whether Delta
label: BODY

text: smelt have dropped below critical population
label: BODY

text: levels. As far as the cause of the decline, said
label: BODY

text: Sommer, scientists are asking themselves where
label: BODY

text: anything has changed in the Delta, and how
label: BODY

text: and why. In 2007, there was increased toxicity
label: BODY

text: in the Delta from contaminants and toxic algae
label: BODY

text: that moved into core Delta smelt habitat, a
label: BODY

text: decline in recruitment and habitat quality,
label: BODY

text: reduced food availability due to invasive species,
label: BODY

text: and increased mortality. There was also more
label: BODY

text: smelt mortality at the pumps in recent winters
label: BODY

text: when pumping increased to the point of creat-
label: BODY

text: ing negative flows in Old and Middle rivers, said
label: BODY

text: Sommer. “At this very moment, scientists from
label: BODY

text: all over the world are trying to figure [the POD]
label: BODY

text: out,” said Sommers.
label: BODY

text: U.S. EPA’s Bruce Herbold built upon Sommer’s
label: BODY

text: talk, telling the audience that “scientists have
label: BODY

text: found a lot of what caused the POD, but that’s
label: BODY

text: not going to solve the problem. Everything else
label: BODY

text: is secondary to the fact that there are not many
label: BODY

text: fish out there.” Herbold said that genetic diver-
label: BODY

text: sity in the smelt population may be so low at this
label: BODY

text: point that the viability of their offspring is
label: BODY

text: affected. Another problem is that their fall habitat
label: BODY

text: has shrunk and moved eastward. Why? “We’ve
label: BODY

text: stabilized flows,” said Herbold. “They used to be
label: BODY

text: very variable.” Herbold suggested that the Delta
label: BODY

text: has become more like a lake. “This means less
label: BODY

text: estuarine fish. The POD may have been a tipping
label: BODY

text: point—from a variable estuarine system to a
label: BODY

text: steady state/lake-lagoon type of system.”
label: BODY

text: Fish & Game’s Kathy Hieb broadened the
label: BODY

text: focus from the Delta to the Pacific Ocean,
label: BODY

text: describing how changes in ocean temperatures
label: BODY

text: and nutrients are affecting the Estuary’s aquatic
label: BODY

text: critters. In warm water years, Dungeness crab
label: BODY

text: have poor embryo and larval survival, while
label: BODY

text: Pacific herring, which go back and forth
label: BODY

text: between the Bay and the ocean to spawn and
label: BODY

text: rear, respond poorly to El Niño years. “They
label: BODY

text: prey on zooplankton,” said Hieb. “When the
label: BODY

text: ocean is warmer, there are less zooplankton.”
label: BODY

text: With warmer ocean temperatures, Hieb pre-
label: BODY

text: dicted, there will be poor recruitment of cold
label: BODY

text: temperature species, and migration to the Bay
label: BODY

text: of more warm water tropical species. She also
label: BODY

text: predicted more “dead zones” from toxic algal
label: BODY

text: blooms, caused by the increase in nutrients result-
label: BODY

text: ing from warmer water.
label: BODY

text: U.S. Fish & Wildlife’s Joelle Buffa
label: BODY

text: switched the focus to mammals, dis-
label: BODY

text: cussing the state of the endangered salt
label: BODY

text: marsh harvest mouse and harbor seals at
label: BODY

text: South Bay refuges. Buffa described how
label: BODY

text: managers have taken various actions,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Buffa. “Translocation can be successful

text: where the population is low and where
label: BODY

text: you create high tide refugia.”
label: BODY

text: USGS’s John Takekawa presented an
label: BODY

text: avian perspective on the Bay—which,
label: BODY

text: because there are so many species of
label: BODY

text: birds with such different lifestyles—is
label: BODY

text: complicated. “If you don’t have long-
label: BODY

text: term data, it is very hard to make sense
label: BODY

text: of complex phenomena,” said Takekawa.
label: BODY

text: He and his colleagues are now studying
label: BODY

text: the movements of individually marked
label: BODY

text: birds. One surprise was that the South
label: BODY

text: Bay’s Colma Creek, surrounded by indus-
label: BODY

text: try, is one of the most important spots for
label: BODY

text: clapper rails in the entire Bay. With multiple
label: BODY

text: restoration projects taking place around the Bay,
label: BODY

text: said Takekawa, resource managers need to keep
label: BODY

text: looking at all of the projects from a bird’s eye
label: BODY

text: view to evaluate their effects. He added that
label: BODY

text: migratory birds responded quickly to South Bay
label: BODY

text: salt pond restoration, with overall numbers
label: BODY

text: increasing at the ponds. “But will mudflat values
label: BODY

text: be decreased?” he asked. “A small change in the
label: BODY

text: elevations of mudflats could make a different to
label: BODY

text: shorebirds if we start having sea level rise. Their
label: BODY

text: time for foraging could be decreased, along

text: with a corresponding decrease in population.”

text: The morning session of Day Two refocused
label: BODY

text: on the Delta. The CALFED Science Program’s
label: BODY

text: Michael Healey said that as sea level rises, new
label: BODY

text: development will need to be better planned to
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: future is not going to be the same as today,”
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Public Policy Institute’s Ellen Hanak gave
label: BODY

text: an overview of the Delta’s value to society—
label: BODY

text: water supply, agriculture, ecosystems, infrastructure,
label: BODY

text: DEC
label: BODY

text: recreation, and hunting, among others. With the
label: BODY

text: housing market slowing down at least temporar-
label: BODY

text: ily, said Hanak, there might be a short-term

label: BODY

text: “There’s the real possibility that we could
label: BODY

text: encounter big problems in the Delta before a
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: two-thirds risk of a catastrophic failure over the
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Delta Risk Management Strategy study examin-

text: Following on the carbon theme, USGS’s
label: BODY

text: Roger Fujii described how a pilot project at
label: BODY

text: Twitchell Island flooded tules to encourage
label: BODY

text: decomposition, and rebuilt subsided soils at the
label: BODY

text: same time. As the tules die and decay, the
label: BODY

text: marsh sequesters carbon dioxide at higher rates
label: BODY

text: than agricultural fields. With microbial decom-
label: BODY

text: position offset by biomass accretion, the land
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Delta’s accommodation space (the “huge hole”
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: ide sequestered would equal the reduction in
label: BODY

text: The afternoon session broadened the focus to
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: the salt pond restoration project, discussing its

text: Coastal plant ecologist Peter Baye addressed
label: BODY

text: the fact that many of our tidal marsh restoration
label: BODY

text: projects have not included rare plants that could
label: BODY

text: be collected from remnant sites and propagated,
label: BODY

text: helping to ensure their survival as species. One
label: BODY

text: example is a rare salt marsh owl’s clover that still
label: BODY

text: exists in Whittell Marsh near Point Pinole.
label: BODY

text: “Almost none of these rare species are finding
label: BODY

text: homes in tidal marsh restoration sites,” said
label: BODY

text: Baye. “Even where there are well-developed
label: BODY

text: marsh plains and channels, 30 years later [these
label: BODY

text: restoration projects] still support only the most
label: BODY

text: common tidal marsh species.” Discussing the
label: BODY

text: restored Muzzi Marsh, Baye pointed out that no
label: BODY

text: uncommon species have dispersed from nearby
label: BODY

text: Heerdt Marsh, the oldest prehistoric marsh in
label: BODY

text: the area, to colonize Muzzi. Baye ended with a
label: BODY

text: series of recommendations for encouraging
label: BODY

text: diversity, including designing restoration
label: BODY

text: marshes more creatively.
label: BODY

text: Creativity has been critical in restoring the
label: BODY

text: Napa River, according to Napa County Flood
label: BODY

text: Control’s Richard Thomasser, who described the
label: BODY

text: history of this multiyear, multi-stakeholder, multi-
label: BODY

text: objective effort. After the Army Corps presented a
label: BODY

text: plan to channelize the river in concrete in the
label: BODY

text: 1960s (and again in the 1990s), the community
label: BODY

text: demanded that any plan for flood control also be
label: BODY

text: a plan for a “living river” that would connect the
label: BODY

text: river to its historical floodplain. As a result, the
label: BODY

text: consensus-based project includes a geomorphic
label: BODY

text: channel design that will restore proper sediment
label: BODY

text: transport balance, and the creation of 650 acres
label: BODY

text: of wetlands. Five major bridges are being made
label: BODY

text: higher and longer to free up hydraulic constric-
label: BODY

text: tions, and to span the channel and the new
label: BODY

text: marshplains, said Thomasser; two bridges were
label: BODY

text: completely rebuilt. “The river and habitat now
label: BODY

text: have some room to move.”
label: BODY

text: The S.F. Regional Board’s Bruce Wolfe gave an
label: BODY

text: overview of his agency’s efforts to protect both
label: BODY

text: rivers and marshes. “We’re better regulating
label: BODY

text: development of upland areas,” said Wolfe. “We
label: BODY

text: are now trying to manage flows better than we
label: BODY

text: have and the changes in runoff patterns that
label: BODY

text: development causes.” Wolfe said his agency no
label: BODY

text: longer takes water quality-based effluent limits
label: BODY

text: from a national list, but instead tackles them on
label: BODY

text: a statewide and regional basis. “TMDLs are
label: BODY

text: really watershed plans,” said Wolfe. “We are
label: BODY

text: now looking at wetlands and streams as a physi-
label: BODY

text: cal unit. Wetlands are really the deltas of riparian
label: BODY

text: systems.” Another change at his agency, said
label: BODY

text: Wolfe, is recognizing that riparian zones have
label: BODY

text: many benefits.
label: BODY

text: The Coastal Conservancy’s Steve Ritchie built
label: BODY

text: upon the “deltas” idea. As the salt pond restora-
label: BODY

text: tion project nears the end of its five-year
label: BODY

text: planning process, said Ritchie, “what about the
label: BODY

text: ponds’ connection to local watersheds?” But
label: BODY

text: making that connection might be complicated.
label: BODY

text: “It’s flood protection with restoration, not just a
label: BODY

text: fun little restoration project,” said Ritchie.
label: BODY

text: Perhaps the most poignant example of trying
label: BODY

text: to integrate restoration into watershed manage-
label: BODY

text: ment and water supply was that of the long-term
label: BODY

text: efforts to restore steelhead to Alameda Creek,
label: BODY

text: the focus of the afternoon session. The National
label: BODY

text: Marine Fisheries Services’ Maura Moody started
label: BODY

text: off by describing the recovery plan being drafted
label: BODY

text: for Central California Coast salmon and steel-
label: BODY

text: head. The Center for Ecosystem Management
label: BODY

text: and Restoration’s Andy Gunther said that the
label: BODY

text: creeks that connect to the Bay are under
label: BODY

text: increasing pressure. “Choosing restoration will
label: BODY

text: require that we conduct experiments on how to
label: BODY

text: restore steelhead trout. Their fight upstream is
label: BODY

text: both mysterious and inspiring. Returning these
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: said Gunther. The lifecycle and impact these fish
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: tions,” said Gunther.
label: BODY

text: The Alameda County Water District’s Eric
label: BODY

text: Cartwright described some of the physical barri-
label: BODY

text: ers that will need to be addressed to restore
label: BODY

text: passage for these fish. “The question is how to
label: BODY

text: provide passage through the flood control chan-
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: channel provides,” said Cartwright. When the
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: for fish passage, said Cartwright. However, the
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: eral studies that the District can remove the
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: nel permanently. At the upper rubber dam, the
label: BODY

text: District will build a fish ladder and install fish
label: BODY

text: screens at several intake structures. Other chal-
label: BODY

text: lenges include funding and instream flows.
label: BODY

text: The Alameda Creek Alliance’s Jeff Miller gave
label: BODY

text: an historical overview of steelhead presence in
label: BODY

text: the watershed, describing how Calaveras Dam,
label: BODY

text: built in 1925, cut off access to the best habitat.
label: BODY

text: The watershed also supported coho and
label: BODY

text: Chinook salmon at one time, said Miller, and
label: BODY

text: remnant steelhead runs persisted until 1964.
label: BODY

text: Today, steelhead are still trying to make it up the
label: BODY

text: creek, despite its obstacle course. But attitudes
label: BODY

text: have changed during the last two decades, and
label: BODY

text: during the last decade, 27 fish were successfully
label: BODY

text: caught and moved upstream by volunteers,
label: BODY

text: dramatizing the need for fish passage improve-
label: BODY

text: ments. “The visibility and persistence of these
label: BODY

text: fish in showing up every year has galvanized
label: BODY

text: us,” said Miller. The Alliance now has more than
label: BODY

text: 1,500 members and more than 15 agencies
label: BODY

text: cooperating in restoration. Genetic analysis of
label: BODY

text: landlocked fish and anadromous fish below the
label: BODY

text: dams show that their genes are closely related.
label: BODY

text: “The biggest question is whether there will be
label: BODY

text: enough water left in the stream,” said Miller.
label: BODY

text: “Right now, none of the agencies releases flows
label: BODY

text: for fish. The draft EIR [for the Calaveras Dam
label: BODY

text: replacement] does not allow for minimum flows
label: BODY

text: for fish. We’re hoping to work with the SFPUC
label: BODY

text: to address the impacts of these dams.”

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: “Their fight

label: H3

text: Greig was followed by Collin Eagles-Smith,
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Eagles-Smith examined mercury concentrations in
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Forster’s tern, and Caspian tern adults, chicks,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Caspian terns, scoters, and avocets. Risk to
label: BODY

text: hatching success is greatest in the South Bay,
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: of whether population impacts might be occur-
label: BODY

text: ring. “This is striking and concerning,” said
label: BODY

text: Eagles-Smith.
label: BODY

text: Kevin Kelley from CSU Long Beach moved
label: BODY

text: from birds to fish, describing the results of his
label: BODY

text: studies on Pacific staghorn sculpin and shiner
label: BODY

text: perch. He has found PCBS, PAHs, and chlori-
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: works sites,” said Kelley.

text: Tracy Collier of NOAA and Sandie O’Neill of
label: BODY

text: the Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: toxics in Puget Sound, pointing to the need for
label: BODY

text: a biological observation system for toxic conta-
label: BODY

text: minants. “If you just look at the sediment
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: bays, Puget Sound is not that contaminated,”
label: BODY

text: said Collier. Yet biologically based monitoring
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: web, including PCBs in herring, said Collier.
label: BODY

text: “You would not have predicted that from sedi-
label: BODY

text: ment and water measurements.”

text: Steve Bay, of the Southern California Coastal
label: BODY

text: Water Research Project Authority, wrapped up

text: the session on the biological effects of pollution.
label: BODY

text: Bay showed how his project uses a “multiple
label: BODY

text: lines of evidence” approach to integrate chem-
label: BODY

text: istry, toxicity, and benthic fauna data to provide

text: an overall assessment of sediment conditions in
label: BODY

text: California. Most of S.F. Bay fell into the “possibly

label: BODY

text: toring stations showed significant sediment
label: BODY

text: toxicity, said Bay.

text: Midday, talk turned to trash, specifically to
label: BODY

text: the overwhelming plastic problem in the
label: BODY

text: Estuary, its creeks, and the ocean. Moderator
label: BODY

text: Larry Kolb estimated that the number of plastic
label: BODY

text: bags—a frequent visitor to the Bay and its creeks
label: BODY

text: and stormdrains—being used by the public aver-
label: BODY

text: ages out to one bag per person per day. In the

text: Bay Area, with seven million people, said Kolb, if
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: would still amount to 7,000 bags per day. Save
label: BODY

text: the Bay’s David Lewis described the overall pot-
label: BODY

text: pourri of trash in the Bay. “It’s not from ships,
label: BODY

text: but from us,” said Lewis, adding that only 20%
label: BODY

text: of water-borne trash comes from boats. Lewis
label: BODY

text: said big sources of trash in Bay creeks are over-
label: BODY

text: flowing or inadequate trash receptacles and

text: direct littering and dumping of household

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Possible partial solutions include Governor
label: BODY

text: Schwarzenegger’s newly formed Ocean Pro-
label: BODY

text: tection Council (tasked with tackling trash) and

text: Coastal Cleanup Days (in 2006, more than

text: 686,000 pounds of trash were removed from

label: BODY

text: behavior while some cities are implementing
label: BODY

text: source reduction, banning plastic bags and
label: BODY

text: Styrofoam food containers. Lewis would like to
label: BODY

text: see the S.F. Regional Board implement stronger
label: BODY

text: stormwater permits regarding trash. Trash sepa-
label: BODY

text: rators and booms will work but not unless they

text: are mandatory, said Lewis. “The Water Board
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: California that help divert trash before it ends up
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: shame,” said Lewis.

text: Lewis was followed by Nute Engineering’s Steve
label: BODY

text: Moore, formerly of the S.F. Regional Board, who,
label: BODY

text: while working there, designed and undertook a
label: BODY

text: “trash rapid assessment” study to examine the
label: BODY

text: sources, patterns, and amounts of trash in Bay
label: BODY

text: Area waterways. With Board co-workers, Moore
label: BODY

text: surveyed 26 creeks around the Bay, from Petal-
label: BODY

text: uma to San Mateo, looked for longitudinal
label: BODY

text: patterns in the watersheds they surveyed, and

label: BODY

text: return rate. Oakland’s Peralta Creek scored the

label: BODY

text: waste and syringes. “We had to stop out of con-
label: BODY

text: cern for our own health at one point,” recalled
label: BODY

text: Moore. On 93 site visits, Moore’s team picked up
label: BODY

text: more than 25,000 pieces of trash, or three pieces

text: for every foot of stream. Half of the trash was
label: BODY

text: plastic, followed by glass and paper. The highest
label: BODY

text: trash deposition rates were found in both wet

text: and dry weather. “We have to address trash in

text: said Moore. “It’s either being tossed, washed, or

text: pipe-shed. “As the low point in the landscape,

text: these streams are sticky places,” said Moore.
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: sheds across all socioeconomic strata. “We need

text: Concluding the pollution session, UCLA’s

text: Assessing progress on the Baylands Ecosystem
label: BODY

text: Habitat Goals, Carl Wilcox of Cal Fish & Game
label: BODY

text: recalled a colleague’s optimism in 1995: “We’ll
label: BODY

text: do this in six months and 50 pages or less.”
label: BODY

text: Four years and countless meetings later, the
label: BODY

text: goals—a biologically based vision for ecosystem
label: BODY

text: restoration—launched a new era in Bay conser-
label: BODY

text: vation, providing guidance for the S.F. Bay Joint
label: BODY

text: Venture, the South Bay Salt Ponds Restoration
label: BODY

text: Project, and county-level Habitat Conservation
label: BODY

text: Plans. Next step: linkage with anticipated
label: BODY

text: Subtidal, Upland, and Streams Habitat Goals,
label: BODY

text: and with CALFED’s Ecosystem Restoration
label: BODY

text: Program.
label: BODY

text: NOAA Fisheries’ Korie Schaeffer gave an
label: BODY

text: update on the process of establishing goals for
label: BODY

text: managing and restoring S.F. Bay’s “hidden” sub-
label: BODY

text: tidal habitat. “The focus will be on habitats we
label: BODY

text: want to see more of or in better condition,” she
label: BODY

text: said. Her group is factoring in human stressors.
label: BODY

text: “We can’t just wave our arms and come up with
label: BODY

text: some goals without realizing past impacts are
label: BODY

text: still active,” she said. A final goals document is
label: BODY

text: expected by December 2008.
label: BODY

text: Nancy Schaefer of Land Conservation
label: BODY

text: Services, Stuart Weiss of the Center for Earth
label: BODY

text: Observation, and Ryan Branciforte of GreenInfo
label: BODY

text: Network discussed another goal-setting project,
label: BODY

text: this one for upland habitat. Phase 1 involves
label: BODY

text: identifying how much land in what kind of con-
label: BODY

text: dition will be needed to conserve the Bay Area’s
label: BODY

text: upland biodiversity, racing against urban sprawl.
label: BODY

text: Vegetation mapping is already completed. Weiss
label: BODY

text: said goals include preserving 90% of globally
label: BODY

text: rare habitat and allowing room for ecosystems
label: BODY

text: to change. He foresaw partnerships with private
label: BODY

text: landowners, including ranchers. “In grassland, a
label: BODY

text: moderate amount of grazing is really the key to
label: BODY

text: management over large areas,” he said.
label: BODY

text: U.S. Fish & Wildlife’s Eric Tattersall took on the
label: BODY

text: contentious subject of habitat conservation plan-
label: BODY

text: ning. “If regional HCP is done the right way, we
label: BODY

text: end up preserving large functioning ecosystems,”
label: BODY

text: he said, while project-by-project approaches lead
label: BODY

text: to fragmented habitat. Tattersall described
label: BODY

text: recently permitted plans in Santa Clara County
label: BODY

text: and east Contra Costa County, and a pending
label: BODY

text: plan in Solano County. “Every successful plan
label: BODY

text: has a political champion who can bring it to
label: BODY

text: fruition,” he concluded.
label: BODY

text: Turning to the past, SFEI’s Robin Grossinger
label: BODY

text: looked at historical ecosystems as guides to
label: BODY

text: restoration. “The historical landscape may be
label: BODY

text: even more directly relevant than we had real-
label: BODY

text: ized,” he said. “Our society took over this
label: BODY

text: landscape quite suddenly. We didn’t ask for the
label: BODY

text: owner’s manual.” Using old maps and written
label: BODY

text: records, Grossinger is attempting to identify the
label: BODY

text: wet and dry places, the intermittent streams,
label: BODY

text: and the overlooked “B-side” habitat types, like
label: BODY

text: sycamore alluvial woodland. Remnant seasonal
label: BODY

text: wetlands in Santa Clara and Napa counties “are
label: BODY

text: tiny fragments of former perennial wetlands. If
label: BODY

text: you’re interested in wetland restoration, historic
label: BODY

text: wetlands show you where to look.”
label: BODY

text: If ecological history can be obscure, the
label: BODY

text: future of estuarine environments is up for
label: BODY

text: grabs—with climate change a prime source of
label: BODY

text: uncertainty. PWA’s Jeremy Lowe said S.F. Bay’s
label: BODY

text: marshes have handled historic sea level rises
label: BODY

text: well. “But sea level rise will accelerate. Will the
label: BODY

text: marshes keep up?” he asked. As the waters rise,
label: BODY

text: mudflat and marsh systems tend to move land-
label: BODY

text: ward—if enough sediment is available. In the
label: BODY

text: long-term, we may need to recharge mudflats
label: BODY

text: with dredge soil. Lowe discussed tradeoffs
label: BODY

text: between leaving levees in place for wave protec-
label: BODY

text: tion and reconnecting marsh and mudflat, and
label: BODY

text: possible engineering fixes.
label: BODY

text: Naomi Feger of the S.F. Regional Board and
label: BODY

text: Roger Leventhal of FarWest Restoration Engineer-
label: BODY

text: ing titled their joint presentation “Sediment—the
label: BODY

text: Good, the Bad and the Buried.” Feger presented
label: BODY

text: case studies of three remediation efforts using
label: BODY

text: Steve Moore
label: BODY

label: H4

text: there have been surprises, like the challenge of
label: BODY

text: dealing with dissolved oxygen. “You don’t always
label: BODY

text: know what you don’t know,” said Morris.
label: BODY

text: In his talk on restoring Delta ecosystems,
label: BODY

text: Stuart Siegel of Wetlands and Water Resources
label: BODY

text: called this huge area “a case study in complex-
label: BODY

text: ity.” Manmade changes—diking islands,
label: BODY

text: shortening channels—complicate the goal of
label: BODY

text: maintaining “viable populations of desirable
label: BODY

text: species. In the Delta, we don’t say ‘native’; there
label: BODY

text: are some non-natives people like to have, like
label: BODY

text: striped bass.” Climate change introduces further
label: BODY

text: complexities. “Wetlands can move up gentle
label: BODY

text: slopes as sea level rises, but not with levees,”
label: BODY

text: Siegel said. He sketched ideas emerging from
label: BODY

text: current planning efforts, including new flood-
label: BODY

text: plains and “green” levees.
label: BODY

text: When S.F. State University’s Tom Parker took
label: BODY

text: the podium, it was late in the day. “When I go
label: BODY

text: to conferences, usually by this time I’m out
label: BODY

text: drinking somewhere,” he quipped. But his mes-
label: BODY

text: sage was no joke: global climate change imperils
label: BODY

text: the Estuary’s marshes. Temperature increase may
label: BODY

text: decrease primary production; inundation and
label: BODY

text: flooding will increase, with restored marsh sites
label: BODY

text: inundated more than natural sites. Rising salinity
label: BODY

text: will reduce species diversity. “Given temperature
label: BODY

text: and salinity increase and marsh accretion rates
label: BODY

text: failing to keep up with sea level rise, what’s the
label: BODY

text: scenario?” he asked. “The winner is pickle-
label: BODY

text: weed,” which occurs now in a variety of salinity
label: BODY

text: and inundation conditions. But it’s more sensi-
label: BODY

text: tive to salinity in poorly drained sites. So an
label: BODY

text: increase in salinity and inundation will signifi-
label: BODY

text: cantly reduce wetland productivity, “especially in
label: BODY

text: pickleweed, the one species most likely to
label: BODY

text: expand under those conditions.”
label: BODY

text: Closing the restoration session, Peggy Olofson
label: BODY

text: of the Invasive Spartina Project reported on the
label: BODY

text: ongoing war against aggressive hybrid cordgrass
label: BODY

text: strains (see ESTUARY, October 2007). She called
label: BODY

text: for the development of best practices for
label: BODY

text: regional agencies. “Monitor and remove it—just
label: BODY

text: monitoring has gotten us nowhere,” she said.
label: BODY

text: “Don’t open a new marsh too early near existing
label: BODY

text: hybrid Spartina. And be careful with equipment
label: BODY

text: and dredge sediment.”

label: BODY

text: Slough, and the Peninsula Sportsmen’s Club (the
label: BODY

text: last a lead-shot contamination site). Leventhal

text: noted some “regulatory discomfort with using

text: Next up was San Jose State University profes-

label: BODY

text: H.T. Harvey, who has spent 50 years studying

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: PRBO Conservation Science’s Nadav Nur
label: BODY

text: reviewed birds as indicators of marsh restoration
label: BODY

text: success, measured by demographic metrics:
label: BODY

text: reproductive success, recruitment of juveniles,
label: BODY

text: survival of adults, emigration, and immigration.
label: BODY

text: He said local-scale data is important. “There’s
label: BODY

text: concern that restoration sites are ecological
label: BODY

text: traps—sinks, not sources.” Nur documented dif-
label: BODY

text: ferent patterns for different bird species. Mature
label: BODY

text: marsh sites had a 1,500% higher density of salt
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: sites. However, song sparrow nestling survival
label: BODY

text: rates were highest in some of the restored
label: BODY

text: marshes. Biologists are also looking at demo-
label: BODY

text: graphics of California clapper rails, great blue
label: BODY

text: herons, and upland songbirds.
label: BODY

text: Christy Smith of the San Pablo Bay National
label: BODY

text: Wildlife Refuge reported on tidal marsh restora-
label: BODY

text: tion and enhancement projects at Tolay Creek,
label: BODY

text: Tubbs Island, and Cullinan Ranch, each present-
label: BODY

text: ing its own set of challenges. At Cullinan Ranch,

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Smith’s South Bay counterpart, Clyde Morris of
label: BODY

text: the Don Edwards S.F. Bay National Wildlife
label: BODY

text: Refuge, looked back on seven restoration projects
label: BODY

text: spanning 20 years. “It must have been really fun
label: BODY

text: back in the 80s to restore things,” he said. “You
label: BODY

text: didn’t worry too much about permits, and plans
label: BODY

text: were something you did on the back of an enve-
label: BODY

text: lope.” But he’s seen things improve—with the
label: BODY

text: South Bay Salt Pond Restoration, “for the first
label: BODY

text: time in my career we’re doing adaptive manage-
label: BODY

text: ment instead of knee-jerk management.” Still
label: BODY

text: LAND USE: MAKING CONNECTIONS
label: BODY

text: That land-dependent creatures—and the
label: BODY

text: farms and other upland areas they inhabit—are
label: BODY

text: in some way related to estuaries was once a for-
label: BODY

text: eign concept. But now, said U.C. Davis’s Jeff
label: BODY

text: Loux at the land use session of October’s confer-
label: BODY

text: ence, “It’s self-evident that water and land use
label: BODY

text: planning are linked.” And as the state’s popula-
label: BODY

text: tion grows, that link will need to tighten,
label: BODY

text: requiring multiple agencies—city planning
label: BODY

text: departments, utilities districts, water agencies,
label: BODY

text: and transportation departments—at local and
label: BODY

text: regional levels to work together more closely.
label: BODY

text: “The region will add five more Oaklands by
label: BODY

text: 2035,” said the Joint Policy Committee’s Ted
label: BODY

text: Droetthoom, commenting that growth will have
label: BODY

text: to be planned much more carefully to mitigate
label: BODY

text: the additional traffic and its effects on air and
label: BODY

text: water quality. Regional bodies like ABAG are
label: BODY

text: finally looking into the nexus among air quality,
label: BODY

text: land use, transportation, and water quality. “Our
label: BODY

text: land use patterns will dictate the need for better
label: BODY

text: transit,” said ABAG’s Dave Burch.
label: BODY

text: Municipalities and regional bodies are trying to
label: BODY

text: focus growth in specific areas to direct planning
label: BODY

text: and investments into “priority development areas,”
label: BODY

text: said ABAG’s Ken Kirkey. A key element of priority
label: BODY

text: development areas is proximity to transit, so that
label: BODY

text: driving can be reduced to create what Cities 21’s
label: BODY

text: Steve Raney called a “low-miles community.”
label: BODY

text: The projections for the Bay Area’s growth
label: BODY

text: mean that managers and policymakers will need
label: BODY

text: to get creative about where to put people and
label: BODY

text: how to make those living places more sustain-
label: BODY

text: able, the topic of a panel discussion in the
label: BODY

text: afternoon session. “We want to make it so that
label: BODY

text: people get to as much as they can on foot,” said
label: BODY

text: the Greenbelt Alliance’s Marla Wilson. To accom-
label: BODY

text: plish that, cities must build compactly and have
label: BODY

text: walkable streets and neighborhoods, and they
label: BODY

text: need to write these ideas into their general plans.
label: BODY

text: “That gives elected officials the will to do it,” said
label: BODY

text: Laurel Prevetti of the City of San Jose.
label: BODY

text: Prevetti noted that in the 1970s, San Jose
label: BODY

text: officials drew a line around the city, indicating
label: BODY

text: its boundary for growth. That forced later
label: BODY

text: administrations to recycle land—developing infill
label: BODY

text: on grayfields like underused parking lots. Much
label: BODY

text: of the development of the 1970s and 1980s also
label: BODY

text: resulted in office parks—large buildings sur-
label: BODY

text: rounded by huge parking lots. One way that
label: BODY

text: nature has been brought back to such environs,
label: BODY

text: said Prevetti, is through greenways and restored
label: BODY

text: urban streams.
label: BODY

text: The topic of creek restoration brought insight
label: BODY

text: from the S.F. Regional Board’s Ann Riley, who
label: BODY

text: described how creeks can be creatively inte-
label: BODY

text: grated into cities, such as in San Luis Obispo.
label: BODY

text: When it comes to restoring streams in cities,
label: BODY

text: said Riley, one of the most common problems is
label: BODY

text: negotiating for more room for the stream—

text: “Hardworking” is the first word most
label: BODY

text: people use to describe Marcia, followed
label: BODY

text: closely by “dedicated.” She has always
label: BODY

text: answered her own phone, usually
label: BODY

text: returns calls or emails within hours,
label: BODY

text: and never fails to ask about the kids.
label: BODY

text: At the eleventh hour of any inter-
label: BODY

text: minable meeting, she can always
label: BODY

text: muster a twinkle in her eye, a wide
label: BODY

text: smile and a good joke, not to mention
label: BODY

text: a knowing look that hints at the wis-
label: BODY

text: dom she’s gathered in all these years of
label: BODY

text: educating the community about the
label: BODY

text: Bay and Delta.

text: 1993,” she says. “The Bay-Delta

text: Accord was signed the following year,

text: support and hoopla from the state and
label: BODY

text: feds. Since then, in all honesty, the

label: BODY

label: BODY
